summary.raw:
Adding Keaton's spectral integration routines.  Very important if you need better than 1% accuracy.

Replacing the simps() integration with Keaton's spectral integration.
To do this, you need to define a workspace variable like `KE` using:
```
KE = field_manager.get_field(domain)
```
Then you can do physical space computations of energy
```
def KE_func(ur, uh, rho0):
    # inherits KE globally
    KE['X'] = rho0*(1./2.*(ur['X']*np.conj(ur['X'])+uh['X']*np.conj(uh['X'])))
    return KE
```
and spectra integrations
```
def compute_average(f, x, z):
    # do Keaton's spectral integration
    # inherits domain globally
    return domain.integrate(f).real
```

See `tests/2D/gwaves_anelastic/gwaves.py` or
`tests/2D/gwaves_PI/gwaves_integrate.py` for implementations of this.
I'll propagate it through the other tests later.

--Ben Brown, 5/8/13, 5pm
summary.html:
Adding Keaton's spectral integration routines. Very important if you need better than 1% accuracy.

Replacing the simps() integration with Keaton's spectral integration.
To do this, you need to define a workspace variable like KE using:

KE = field_manager.get_field(domain)

Then you can do physical space computations of energy

def KE_func(ur, uh, rho0):
    # inherits KE globally
    KE['X'] = rho0*(1./2.*(ur['X']*np.conj(ur['X'])+uh['X']*np.conj(uh['X'])))
    return KE

and spectra integrations

def compute_average(f, x, z):
    # do Keaton's spectral integration
    # inherits domain globally
    return domain.integrate(f).real

See tests/2D/gwaves_anelastic/gwaves.py or
tests/2D/gwaves_PI/gwaves_integrate.py for implementations of this.
I'll propagate it through the other tests later.

--Ben Brown, 5/8/13, 5pm

values.message:
Adding Keaton's spectral integration routines.  Very important if you need better than 1% accuracy.

Replacing the simps() integration with Keaton's spectral integration.
To do this, you need to define a workspace variable like `KE` using:
```
KE = field_manager.get_field(domain)
```
Then you can do physical space computations of energy
```
def KE_func(ur, uh, rho0):
    # inherits KE globally
    KE['X'] = rho0*(1./2.*(ur['X']*np.conj(ur['X'])+uh['X']*np.conj(uh['X'])))
    return KE
```
and spectra integrations
```
def compute_average(f, x, z):
    # do Keaton's spectral integration
    # inherits domain globally
    return domain.integrate(f).real
```

See `tests/2D/gwaves_anelastic/gwaves.py` or
`tests/2D/gwaves_PI/gwaves_integrate.py` for implementations of this.
I'll propagate it through the other tests later.

--Ben Brown, 5/8/13, 5pm

summary.raw:
Doing decay tests; with	S-diffusion, decay works properly once t or R_inv is rescaled.

Remember: inverse wave reynolds	number is R_inv/(k^2) in some sense,
and if you don't do this then the perturbations will diffuse wildly
quickly.  It's working better right now, but still not perfect.  Hmm.

--Ben Brown, 10/4/13, noon
summary.html:
Doing decay tests; with S-diffusion, decay works properly once t or R_inv is rescaled.

summary.raw:
Fixing boundary conditions in gwaves (adiabatic); general tidying up.

The boundary conditions need to apply on the ur and div(u) equations;
both uh and S equations are algebraic in z (they have no dependence on
d/dz Q).  Applying BCs on these rows is no good.

The adiabatic anelastic gwaves look good, and their energy trace looks
good (some oscillations in total energy still).
--Ben Brown, 10/4/13

Added 1-D burgers equation test, following Ascher et al 1995.  Works.

Here is a 1-D test of Burgers equation (nonlinear advection test).
We qualitatively reproduce the results of Ascher et al 1995.  Haven't
yet done a quantitative comparison, but a good start.

summary.raw:
Added S-diffusion gwaves.  Caught bug in BC for T diffusion.

In the T diffusion case, I had not updated the BC arrays to match the
new ordering (pomega as last variable).  This lead to spurious rho-dS
and drho-pomega coupled boundary conditions, rather than S-rho and
dS-drho.  That has been fixed now.  Bet that describes the strange
behaviour I was seeing with T-diffusion tests tonight.

--Ben Brown, 10/2/13, 11:30pm

summary.raw:
Added 5th BC on thermal_modes_2d_T.py; now appears to work.

Added an arbitrary boundary condition on u_h at the top boundary.
This seems to allow stable integration.  Clearly, I need some form of
additional B.C., but I'm not sure what, and I'm missing something very
basic.  Time to learn.

--Ben Brown, 10/2/13, 1:30pm

summary.raw:
Added Fourier-Fourier 2D thermal mode T case; Fourier-Chebyshev is still broken.

Turns out the Fourier-Chebyshev thermal modes 2d_T also develops
instabilities at long t.  Built a Fourier-Fourier version to check
whether timestepping, etc. is behaving itself.  It is.  That case is
well behaved, decays, and shows no instability.  Clearly a BC problem
(or something involving the timestepping & chebyshevs; but no, the 1D
case is Chebyshev... hmm...).

--Ben Brown, 10/2/13, 1:20pm
summary.html:
Added Fourier-Fourier 2D thermal mode T case; Fourier-Chebyshev is still broken.

summary.raw:
Cleaned up arrays in both 1d and 2d thermal modes problem.  Also, went to only 1 thermal BC in 2d.

The 2d system now seems to be working (decays at least).  Went down to
1 thermal BC.  We have 2 vertical in u (impenetrable), one vertical in
T.  Why does this work?  Something about div.u must be linking
conditions.  I'm confused.

--Ben Brown, 10/2/13, 1:10pm

summary.raw:
Added 1D thermal mode test, in Chebyshev domain.  Works.

The 1D thermal mode test in Chebyshev domains works just fine.  This
was done as a sanity check on the formulation of the equations in the
2D version.  The 2D version is still blowing up.  Something about the
div.u is mucking up the system.

--Ben Brown, 10/2/13, 1pm

summary.raw:
Ported thermal_mode_test to Keaton's branch (e.g., lambda d_trans:); also, added compute_average() to chebyshev test

In Chebyshev domains, we need to be careful about summing over the domain.  Integrating gives different results than summing, as the grid is non-uniform.  This is especially important when calculating energies.

--Ben Brown, 10/1/13, 4pm

summary.raw:
Main change is adding 2D tests of thermal modes.

Made 2D versions of thermal mode problem to test out what in the world
is going wrong with T-diffusion.  I have a feeling that it's boundary
conditions, especially since the doubly-periodic thermal mode test
works, while the Fourier-Chebyshev one totally fails.

I don't understand what is going wrong with boundary conditions in the
2-D systems; a problem for tomorrow (and need to review the
Rayleigh-Benard test).

--Ben Brown, 9/30/13, 11:15pm

summary.raw:
Stratified diffusion tests in anelastic regime; working (S-diffusion).

diffusion.py:
Straight up diffusion test in a stratified atmosphere.  Works.
Perturbations diffuse.

diffusion_plot.py
Plot frames for S and dS to test that diffusion is working.
Visual pass (test timescales later and decay rates).

gwaves_with_S_diffusion.py:
Anelastic gwaves with S_diffusion.  Works.  (and they don't diffuse!)

painful lesson from gwaves_with_S_diffusion.py:
Do not apply boundary conditions on the pomega part of the array.
Leave that zeros all across; lets pomega be completely free?  Need to
understand better the mechanics of the dedalus boundary conditions to
understand this problem.

Note:
I have T and S diffusion coded up in the fully compressible equations,
but am getting some major problems with numerical instability.
At timestep 1, u_h -> 1e9.  Not good.  BC problem?  Will look at in morning.

--Ben Brown, 9/29/13 11:15pm

Caught error in pressure-stratification coupling in FC (and PI) modes while texing up notes.

This seems to resolve the growing acoustic mode problem I was seeing
in the FC tests (see pomega coupling term in L0 matrix).

Texed up notes to be added later this afternoon.

summary.raw:
Added 2-D gwave tests.  These require Keaton's development branch to run.

These require Keaton's branch of Dedalus 2.  I branched my copy at
changeset:   160:e8a0f2353709, so previous to the reworking of diff.

You'll also need my timestepper.py file, modified to work with
Keaton's branch.  I'll add that in a moment in a second commit.

Added 2-D tests for fully compressible (gwaves/) and LBR anelastic
(gwaves_anelastic/) linear wave in isothermal atmosphere tests.

In gwaves/gwaves.py, the fully compressible equations are solved and
both g modes and p modes are visible (p modes are vertically
propagating).

In gwaves_anelastic/gwaves.py, only the g modes are present.

--Ben Brown, 9/27/13, 10am

summary.raw:
Fourier version of thermal mode test; appears to work well.

Modes propagate, wrap periodically across domain boundaries.  The initial conditions for adiabatic_propagating are not in equilibrium and this drives a huge initial T gradient that diffuses; probably a bit spurious.  S-diffusion waves propagate adiabatically, while T-diffusion waves dissipate away.  Nice.

--Ben Brown, 9/25/13, 3:20pm

summary.raw:
Thermal mode test passes T-diffusion tests; can use adiabatic initial conditions with no problem.

New initial conditions, including adiabatic standing waves and adiabatic propagating waves.  Look good.  Standing waves diffuse with T-diffusion, even if initial perturbation is adiabatic or isothermal.

--Ben Brown, 9/25/13, 2:05pm
summary.html:
Thermal mode test passes T-diffusion tests; can use adiabatic initial conditions with no problem.

New initial conditions, including adiabatic standing waves and adiabatic propagating waves. Look good. Standing waves diffuse with T-diffusion, even if initial perturbation is adiabatic or isothermal.

--Ben Brown, 9/25/13, 2:05pm

values.message:
Thermal mode test passes T-diffusion tests; can use adiabatic initial conditions with no problem.

New initial conditions, including adiabatic standing waves and adiabatic propagating waves.  Look good.  Standing waves diffuse with T-diffusion, even if initial perturbation is adiabatic or isothermal.

--Ben Brown, 9/25/13, 2:05pm

summary.raw:
Thermal mode test now works for either T or S diffusion.

The S diffusion case is now recast in terms of the T diffusion time (multiplying \chi_S by gamma and propagating through to R_T as well).  This is behaving stably for MCNAB2 timestepping and the thermal boundaries look good in those cases too (the Dedalus CNAB3 was showing oscillatory instabilities in the thermal boundary layer).  Needs to be checked for other schemes.

Boundaries for fixed S, fixed T, fixed dS and fixed dT are all implemented.  I've tested fixed T for both T and S diffusion (injects energy into the S-diffusion case, leading to a growing mode).  I've likewise tested fixed S and fixed dS for S diffusion (wave goes to adiabatic mode, doesn't grow in energy), but not for T-diffusion nor have I checked fixed dT.

--Ben Brown, 9/25/13, 1:50pm
summary.html:

Needs to be checked for other schemes.

Boundaries for fixed S, fixed T, fixed dS and fixed dT are all implemented. I've tested fixed T for both T and S diffusion (injects energy into the S-diffusion case, leading to a growing mode). I've likewise tested fixed S and fixed dS for S diffusion (wave goes to adiabatic mode, doesn't grow in energy), but not for T-diffusion nor have I checked fixed dT.

summary.raw:
Adding some trivial tests of MPI-based communication, based off of tutorials from the web (see comments).

Started playing with and developing these this afternoon based off of
tutorials on MPI in python with mpi4py.  Some of these work, some
don't (dotproductparallel_1 is showing strange non-blocking behavior
and barrier doesn't seem to do squat).  We'll play and learn.

--Ben Brown, 9/23/13, 3pm

method, but am getting closer.

I also caught a big error in the advection_diffusion_test L1 matrix
(had +b vs. correct -b). Probably other errors lurk.

--Ben Brown, 9/16/13, 4:30pm

values.message:
Playing around with timesteppers (added something like CNAB2); caught big error in L1 matrix for advection_diffusion_test.py

I've done a quick hack on Keaton's timesteppers.py to (maybe) get a
CNAB2 timestepper; I don't fully understand a, b, c, d coeffs in his
method, but am getting closer.

I also caught a big error in the advection_diffusion_test L1 matrix
(had +b vs. correct -b).  Probably other errors lurk.

--Ben Brown, 9/16/13, 4:30pm

summary.raw:
Added verbose flag to dedalus2/pde/integrator.py

Controls whether to output stop messages to terminal.  It's useful to
remove this output when doing many repeated tests (e.g., of the
timestepper stability).

--Ben Brown, 9/16/13, 1:45pm

summary.raw:
Changed xrange to range in liveplot.py

xrange was undefined; appears to have been deprecated in Python3.

As a check, xrange() appears in:
    http://docs.python.org/2/library/functions.html
but is nowhere to be found in:
    http://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html

--Ben Brown, 9/10/13 1pm
